testimony shows Kennedy might have been shielded by Secret Service agent riding on rear step of auto had he not requested earlier that position be vacated; F M Boring and other agents who guarded him at Tampa, Fla, Nov 18 '64, testified that he ordered 2 men riding right and left rear steps to get off and enter follow-up auto; White House detail chief Behn described criteria agents use for motorcade protection; service Chief Rowley testified it is not service practice to have agent ride on rear step at all times; said no Pres would try to tell service what to do and that service cannot tell Pres what to do for his protection; differed from view expressed by Hoover on curbing Pres freedom of action; curbs outlined; Warren queried Rowley closely about 9 agents who visited Ft Worth Press Club night before assassination and drank alcoholic beverages; 4 of them were assigned to Dallas motorcade; Rowley conceded they might have been more alert had they gone to bed earlier but said they could not have prevented killing; admitted agents merited dismissal for violating rules but feared pub would have concluded they were responsible for assassination; Yarborough, who rode 2 autos behind Pres, said agents did not respond quickly enough; comm disputed view; testimony shows service has greatly broadened criteria governing data it seeks from other agencies on Pres safety; Hoover expressed serious concern about broadened criteria and use being made of data it produces

AUSTIN, Tex., Dec. 31 -- President Johnson ended 1964 with one of his few quiet days of the year.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 31 -- The Interstate Commerce Commission rejected an appeal today from small, independent soft-coal mine operators against new and lower railroad freight rates they said would favor the largest companies and put some small mines out of business.
The American Stock Exchange ended the year on a strong upbeat yesterday. Volume soared to a near record figure and advances outnumbered declines by a wide margin.

OCEAN SPRINGS, Miss., Dec. 31 (AP) -- Four members of a Texas family died today in a collision involving three cars and a gasoline truck on a foggy Gulf Coast highway here. A fifth person died later at a hospital.
BERLIN, Dec. 31 (AP) -- West Berliners streamed through the Communist wall today to greet the New Year with their relatives in East Berlin.

Phil Silvers may return to television next fall on the Columbia Broadcasting System network. It was reported yesterday that Warner Brothers would begin production of a half-hour pilot film in Hollywood next week.

BERKELEY, Calif., Dec. 31 -An early peace for the turmoil-ridden Berkeley campus of the University of California was predicted today by faculty leaders.

Washington's refusal to accept another military coup evidently has led to second thoughts among the young generals, including ex-Premier Khanh. It would be an error now to accept a face-saving compromise that simply goes back to the status quo ante.

THE new year was given a rather weak salute last night by the New York Philharmonic. The orchestra was back from its week of vacation, and Thomas Schippers took the podium for his first concert of a six-week stint.

The big paper machines at the plant of Whiting Co., a manufacturer of fine paper in Holyoke, Mass., were turned off permanently yesterday afternoon.

The old year dies, we say, and a new year is at hand. But beyond the counting, the arbitrary division of the year's circle into twelfths, there is no ending; and even with the counting there is no pause, no real completion. The year, the once-around-the-sun, could as well be counted from July to July as from January to January, for it is no more and no less than the sum of the seasons.

DETROIT, Dec. 31 -- Henry Ford 2d expressed today "total disagreement" with a Johnson Administration official who criticized the automobile industry for feeding inflation by failing to cut car prices before 1964 labor negotiations.
SINGAPORE, Friday, Jan. 1 (UPI) -- A group of men wearing black uniform plastered the U.S. information service library early today with anti-American slogans painted in red.

The proposal by the Superintendent of Schools to establish a system of four-year, comprehensive high schools received qualified support yesterday frbm the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People.
WASHINGTON. Dec. 31 (AP) -- Southern schools and colleges stand to lose millions of dollarsi in Federal funds if they do not agree to wipe out every trace of racial discrimination.

The American International Music Fund will benefit from a testimonial dinner in celebration of Dr. Albert Schweitzer's 90th birthday, to be held in the Plaza's Grand Ballroom on Jan. 18.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 31 (AP) -- An out-of-court settlement today brought the dismissal of the $300,000 lawsuit that led to the investigation of Robert G. Baker, former secretary to the Senate Democratic majority.

This year marks the centennial of the birth of Jean Sibelius, Finland's greatest composer, and to celebrate the event, the Finnish Government has declared 1965 "Sibelius Year." As was the ease with the Richard Strauss centennial last year, many concerts and special events will be scheduled here.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 31 -- As the dawn of the New Year draws near over Texas and the other lands east of the International Dateline, President Johnson is building muscle for the construction of a Balanced American Society. He calls it by another name -- the Great Society.
LONDON, Dec. 31 (AP) -- London's most famous boot-makers are closing their custom department because of trouble getting craftsmen.

Leroy McRae, the Socialist Workers party candidate for State Attorney General in 1961 and now an employe of Mobilization for Youth, challenged State Senator John J. Marchi yesterday to prove in court the allegation that Mr. McRae wasl an "extremist."

Prices were marked up at wholesale yesterday by the Procter Gamble Company on its toilet soaps and brands used for washing fine fabrics.

LEOPOLDVILLE the Congo, Dec. 31 -- President Joseph Kasavubu indicated tonight that the Congolese Government would reject the "national reconciliation" called for yesterday by the United Nations Security Council.

The fifth annual institute and brunch of the Greater New York-New Jersey Region of the Brandeis University National Women's Committee will take place at the Waldorf-Astoria on Jan. 7.

Government bond prices reacted yesterday to the Treasury's $33.1 billion advance refunding. Long-term bonds declined and short-term issued inched upward.

LONDON, Dec. 31 -- Two British Army battalions -- about 1,000 men -- are to be flown to the Far East in a "precautionary" move "in view of Indonesia's intensification of her policy of attacking Malaysia."

MONTREAL, Dec. 31 -- Jupiter will usher in the New Year with a burst of intense radio signals, beginning tomorrow at 2 A.M., Eastern standard time, it was predicted at a scientific meeting here today.

BONN, Dec. 31 (AP) -- Chancellor Ludwig Erhard assured President Johnson tonight of continued close relations between West Germany and the United States during 1965.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 31 (AP) -- Retail sales in the week ended Dec. 26 declined 5 per cent from the level of the previous week, but were up 19 per cent from the comparable 1963 week total.

Prospect Park, Brooklyn's classical architectural achievement of the 19th century, was voted $924,000 yesterday for a renovation and for restoration of three neglected landmarks in time for the park's centennial, in 1966.

Bostitch, Inc., disclosed in its annual report issued yesterday net sales of $32,592,157 for the fiscal year ended Aug. 31, against $31,075,199 for the preceding fiscal year.

Free reserves of the commercial banking system dropped sharply to a daily average of $105 million in the week ended Wednesday, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported yesterday.
MANSFIELD, Ohio, Dec. 31 (AP) -- A prosperous state Senator plans to claim unemployment compensation after his term expires tomorrow.

Recent action by Secretary of Defense McNamara concerning the Army Reserve and indications that similar actions will be taken for other Reserve forces prompts the writing of this letter [Editorial Dec. 14].

WASHINGTON, Dec. 31 -- The man who turned out the lights in the White House is considering plans to bathe it in exterior illumination that would look like moonlight and might cost as much as $175,000.
ROME, Dec. 31 -- The new President, Giuseppe Saragat, expressed tonight his hope for the consolidation of world peace and a renewal of economic expansion in Italy.

LONDON, Dec. 31 -- The increasingly difficult military and political predicament confronting the United States in Vietnam is evoking sympathy and bafflement from Washington's allies in Western Europe.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 31 (AP) -- A letter from Dean Burch, explaining to members of the Republican National Committee why he thinks he should remain their National Chairman, was mailed tonight.

Thomas Schippers will double as conductor and pianist in next week's four concerts of the New York Philharmonic at Philharmonic Hall.

An estimate of the Shubert estate will be filed in New York Supreme Court within two weeks, according to Edwin L. Weisl Sr., referee in the litigation.

The nation's scheduled airlines will enter the new year with more than a billion dollars worth of orders placed with manufacturers of flight and ground equipment, the Air Transportation Association reported yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 31 -The Johnson-for-President Committee collected and spent more than $700,000 in the Presidential election campaign this year, a report filed with the clerk of the House of Representatives showed today.

LOS ANGELES, Dec. 31 (AP) -- The program that supplied 100,000 Mexican national farm workers for California fields in 1964 ended tonight.

The American Machine and Foundry Company disclosed yesterday it had placed with institutional investors $95 million of promissory notes due Dec. 1, 1979. The interest rate is 5 per cent.
LAGOS, Nigeria, Dec. 31 -- The President and the Prime Minister of Nigeria were headed for a showdown tonight as turmoil mounted after yesterday's election.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 31 (UPI) -- The computer-conscious Pentagon has come up with a device to place men in new jobs by using machines.

This is the month the out-of-town buyers will be flooding into town to buy apparel for spring and summer selling. The number of buyers to be listed in The New York Times Arrival of Buyers columns on Monday will come to about 1,150, as compared with 1,300 on the corresponding day of 1964.

GEORGETOWN, British Guiana, Dec. 31 -- Former Premier Cheddi B. Jagan and 23 members of his Progressive People's party boycotted today the new Parliament, which met for the swearing in of the 53-member House of Assembly.
Angry leaders of dockworkers threatened yesterday to strike from Maine to Texas, but no deadline was set immediately.

Middle South Utilities, Inc., and subsidiaries reported yesterday gains of 7.3 per cent in operating revenues and 16.2 per cent in net income for the first 11 months of 1964.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 31 -- It would be a foolhardy bookie who would give odds on the election of a Senate Democratic whip to succeed Vice President-elect Hubert H. Humphrey.

The United Nations General Assembly on Tuesday chose Uruguay and the Netherlands for two-year terms on the Security Council and Malaysia for a one-year term. On Thursday, Jordan was chosen for a one-year Council term in 1965 and Mali for a one-year term in 1966.

LONDON, Dec. 31 (UPI) -- British shipyards have new orders that are only enough for two-thirds of their capacity, the president of the Shipbuilding Conference, Allan J. Marr, said today. Total orders at the end of the year were estimated at 2.5 million tons.
An exhibition of the kind of art collected by lawyers will be held at Knoedler Art Galleries, 14 East 57th Street, sponsored by the Association of the Bar of the City of New York.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Dec. 31 -- Various factions here appeared today to be reading into yesterday's Security Council resolution on the Congo whatever each had hoped the resolution would say before it was adopted.

MEXICO CITY, Dec. 31 -- The House of Deputies approved a resolution last night to reform the 1917 Constitution to permit the re-election of deputies after a single term. The bill, passed too late to be sent to the Senate this session, will be considered at the Senate's second session, scheduled for next September.

STEWART MANOR, L.I., Dec. 31 -- A motorist was killed here today when his automobile collided with an empty eastbound train on the Hempstead branch of the Long Island Rail Road. The police said he apparently drove through the closed gate at the Covert Avenue crossing.

LONDON, Dec. 31 -- The man in charge of Scotland Yard's 1,800 detectives deplored today the "wild, reckless and purposeless use of firearms" in recent London crimes but denied that the city had come under "an uncontrollable wave of violence."
JAKARTA, Indonesia, Dec. 31 -- President Sukarno declared tonight that Indonesia will withdraw from the United Nations if Malaysia takes her seat on the Security Council.
The manager of a Times Square currency exchange was wounded by a police bullet yesterday as an 18-year-old robber, cornered by two patrolmen, tried to shoot his way to freedom.

The Lincoln Center Repertory Company has canceled its fourth and final bill of the season, "The Madwoman of Chaillot," and Arthur Miller said yesterday that he was withdrawing his two dramas, "Incident at Vichy" and "After the Fall," from the Anta Washington Square Theater at the end of the season on June. 5.
PARIS, Dec. 31 -- President de Gaulle called on the French people tonight to work harder to hold off American economic penetration and keep France independent of a United States hegemeny.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 31 -- Budget Bureau pressure forced the Department of Agriculture today into some research cutbacks and the reorganization of some functions.

THIS is a time for looking ahead, but perhaps a backward glance at some of the pleasures experienced in the line of duty are in order. Any number of unfortunate incidents could, but won't, be recalled. The fine times are more fun to remember.
The 53d annual Neediest Cases appeal set a record for contributions yesterday, two months before its closing date.
NEW ORLEANS, Dec. 31 (AP) -- Ron Holmberg of New York and Les Sack of Clarksdale, Miss., won the doubles title today in the 28th Sugar Bowl tennis tournament.
HAIFA, Israel -- From the hotel on the crest of Mount Carmel the deep water harbor of Haifa encloses a tranquil corner of the Mediterranean.

CAIRO, Dec. 31 (AP) -- President Gamal Abdel Nasser can expect little if any food from the Soviet Union if the United States cuts off its multimillion-dollar food aid program to the United Arab Republic sources close to the Russians said today.
OTTAWA, Dec. 31 -- Prime Minister Lester B. Pearson rejected today the demands of a rival political leader for a purge of the Liberal Cabinet as the price for needed support.
Mayor Wagner has apparently given up hope of preventing Assemblyman Stanley Steingut of Brooklyn from becoming Speaker when the 1965 Legislature convenes in Albany next Wednesday.

CHICAGO, Dec. 31 (UPI) -- Eddie Jackson's two free throws with one second to play gave Bradley a 74-72 victory over Notre Dame tonight after the Irish made up a 14-point deficit to tie in the final six minutes.

New York City's economy is prospering and more than four million persons in the city's work force are sharing in the boom, City Commerce Commissioner Louis Broido said yesterday in his annual economic forecast.
ALBANY, Dec. 31 -- With the opening of the 1965 Legislature six days away, the prefiling of bills is increasing in tempo.
MOSCOW, Dec. 31 -- Tonight, for the first time in 10 years, there was no New Year's Eve party at the Kremlin.

Chas. Pfizer Co., Inc., announced yesterday the purchase of the outstanding shares of the Dolite Company, Gibsonburg, Ohio, producers of dead-burned dolomite for the steel industry and fine screened limestone. The transaction was made for an undisclosed amount of cash.
GENEVA, Dec. 31 -- The International Press Institute said today that the "most outrageous suppression of press freedom of the year" was the banning of The Daily News of Salisbury, Rhodesia.
NO great fashion came out of 1964, but everybody had a lot of fun.
LAKE MOHAWK, N.J., Dec. 31 -- The parents of a group of teen-agers who attended a "booze and beer" party here Monday night are being asked by the chief of police to "come in for a talk."

LONDON, Friday, Jan. 1 -- Prime Minister Harold Wilson issued today a New Year honors list heavy with the names of athletes, bridge builders and bus drivers whose services are to be given recognition by Queen Elizabeth II.
The leaders of two welfare unions said yesterday they would lead their members out on strike Monday morning, despite a court restraining order, if a contract settlement was not reached with the city.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 31 -About 90,000 unionized soft-coal miners, many of them in the severely depressed mountain counties of the Appalachian region, will get a $1 a day wage increase effective at midnight tonight.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 31 (UPI) -- The Defense Department awarded $41 million in initial contracts today for a jet transport capable of carrying 700 troops at 500 miles an hour.

Dramatic statistics illustrating the fantastic growth of scientific research in the modern world have been presented by Prof. D.J.D. Price of Yale to the American Association for the Advancement of Science at its meeting in Montreal.
Five women and four men were indicted yesterday by a Federal grand jury in Brooklyn on charges of smuggling cocaine into this country from South America.

PASADENA, Calif., Dec. 31 (UPI) -- Oregon State and Michigan, will meet tomorrow in the 51st edition of the oldest of all the post season games, the Rose Bowl.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 31 (AP) -- An official of the International Union of Electrical Workers announced today he was organizing a campaign to oust James B. Carey as union president.

THIS is a day that will put an awful lot of marriages to the supreme test. The noble breadwinner will plunk himself down in front of the television set in the early afternoon and the little lady will have trouble in budging him away from it for the next eight or nine hours. This situation is not ordinarily calculated to embellish the romantic image of matrimony.
PERTH, Australia, Dec. 31 (UPI) -- Donald Campbell and his 10-year-old hydroplane, Bluebird, set a world water speed record today of 276.33 miles an hour.
A city girdled by highway and rail loops that would eliminate midtown congestion and provide "easy commuting" was envisioned for 1965 in a planning report handed down 36 years ago.

SANTIAGO, Chile, Dec. 31 -- Chile's recently announced copper agreements with American companies, based on the "Chileanization" of the vast industry, will be submitted to the Congress next Tuesday, it was announced today by President Eduardo Frei Montalva.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 31 (UPI) -- One day short of his 70th birthday, John Edgar Hoover seems as healthy and determined as he was the day he took over the Federal Bureau of Investigation more than 40 years ago to make it -- and himself -- something close to legends.
The City Planning Commission criticized the Board of Education yesterday for permitting some schools to become overcrowded while others in the same boroughs have seats to spare.
ATLANTA, Dec. 31 (UPI) -- The Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. has sent letters to Congressmen asking them to support an attempt to challenge the seating of Mississippi's Congressional delegation.

LONG ISLAND'S boat-show feud, which is also a battle of the sexes, has reached the sticks-and-stones stage. As a matter of fact, Mrs. Eadie Van Nostrand, the blonde charmer who chopped down rival signs last year with a hatchet; is swinging what amounts to an axe this year.
Jest-a-Fool, the $12.20 winner of yesterday's fourth race at Charles Town, became a year older at 12:01 A.M. today.

Wilt Chamberlain, the biggest attraction in basketball, and Lew Alcindor, the high school star who may deprive Chamberlain of that distinction, both will appear tonight on the Madison Square Garden court.
CORAL GABLES, Fla., Dec. 31 (AP) -- Jacinto Vasquez scored his second triple of the week at Tropical Park today. Two other days he rode double winners.

Soybean futures surprised many traders yesterday by finishing the year and the week on a generally firm note. Earlier in the week, prices had plunged by as much as 14 1/4 cents a bushel in the heaviest trading on record.

The oft-tangled Curtis Publishing Company story closed out the year yesterday on an amicable note, with a joint announcement from the company and two former officials of an out-of-court settlement of their differences.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 31 (AP) -- The Atomic Energy Commission announced a new regulation today against discrimination on the basis of race, creed or color in any activity receiving financial aid from the agency.

Actors Equity has taken umbrage at statements by Edward Albee in The New York Times of Dec. 27, which said that it had not been possible to cast the two leading roles in "Tiny Alice" with American actors because of the play's "difficult language."

A Reform Democratic leader charged yesterday that MacNeil Mitchell, a long-time Republican member of the State Legislature, had directed a redistricting plan that could bring Carmine G. De Sapio, former leader of Tammany, back to political power.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 31 (AP) -- Senate liberals, eager to revise the Senate rules so that filibusters can be terminated more easily, have been invited to strategy talks Sunday.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 31 -- Rail freight traffic volume reached a postwar high in 1964 with an estimated 665 billion ton-miles, the Association of American Railroads announced today. The total represented a 2 per cent increase over the previous postwar high set in 1947.
TOKYO, Dec. 31 -- Premier Eisaku Sato has voiced confidence that he will find in Washington complete understanding of his desire to expand relations between Japan and Communist China.
The New Year rang in cheerily yesterday for four city officials. The City Record disclosed that all four had received salary increases from Mayor Wagner.

The seven-story office building at 799 Seventh Avenue at 52d Street has been sold by the Columbia Broadcasting System to Wellington Associates, real estate concern. The price was reportedly about $3 million.

LONDON, Dec. 31 -- Britain's balance-of-payments deficit in the third quarter increased substantially to 283 million ($792.4 million), the Treasury reported today.
A Queens thrift institution has cut the rate it pays savers. Starting today, accounts in the Bayside Federal Savings and Loan Association will earn 4 per cent instead of 4 1/4 per cent.

The Inland Steel Company announced yesterday that it would begin producing a low-cost substitute for stainless steel in the second quarter of this year.

KARACHI, Pakistan, Dec. 31 -- Opponents of President Mohammed Ayub Khan charged today that his Government was misusing United States aid funds to finance his campaign for re-election. CAIRO, Jan. 1 (UPI) -- An Arab-African bank financed by the United Arab Republic and Kuwait, the "rich uncle" of the Arab world, began preparations today for going into business later this month.
BONN -- The West German Treasury has asked Parliament to approve the partial denationalization of the Vereinigte Elektrizitats und Bergwerks, A.G. (VEBA).

NEW ORLEANS, Jan. 1 (UPI) -- The Federal Government is holding up some of the anti-poverty drive funds earmarked for Louisiana while it investigates "the quality of the personnel being recruited by the state."

THE new stationery in Henri Bendel's street-floor Paper Shop is vibrant with color. The writing paper was designed by Mrs. John L. Strong, who has long supplied titled names with appropriate stationery from her shop on Madison Avenue.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 1 -- The Administration is hopeful that the United Nations Security Council's call for nonintervention in Africa has opened the door to a solution of the Congo crisis by Africans.
The Colorado scientist who predicted that a burst of radio signals from Jupiter would reach earth New Year's Eve said yesterday that the emissions had come in on schedule.

Mrs. Consuelo Vanderbilt Balsan bequeathed the bulk of her estate, her mansion in Southampton, L.I., and her collection of jewels to her favorite granddaughter, Mrs. Edwin F. Russell of 1 Sutton Place South.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 1 -- President Johnson began today the process of reassigning United States Ambassadors around the world with the announcement that new envoys had been named to serve in Venezuela and Ecuador.
PASADENA, Calif., Jan. 1 -- The Michigan Wolverines smashed the Oregon State Beavers, 34 to 7, today in the 51st Rose Bowl game before an impressed capacity crowd of 100,423.

ROME, Jan. 1 -- Pope Paul VI today renewed his plea for world peace, especially in those areas where "brothers kill brothers" and "oppression, revenge, war are still believed to be the instruments of order and peace."

PORT WASHINGTON, L.I., Jan. 1 -- Joseph G. Burbeck of the Larchmont Interclub fleet turned in a remarkable performance with two firsts and a second today as a record fleet of 106 boats in three dinghy classes began competition in the New Year regatta on Manhasset Bay.
An unusual one-side-only long playing record has been made by Victor Borge, who plans to sell it for $100 a copy to raise money for scholarships for Danish students.
MacNeil Mitchell scoffed yesterday at charges that he had directed a redistricting plan that could bring Carmine G. De Sapio, former leader of Tammany, back into political power.
LEOPOLDVILLE, the Congo, Jan. 1 -- A Scottish missionary lost his life in the northeastern Congo because he refused to abandon an American colleague who had been condemned to death by the rebels.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia. Jan. 1 -- Reports reaching here indicate that the Council of Mutual Economic Assistance, or Comecon, the Communist organization promoting the economic integration of East Europe, is undergoing a radical transformation.
MOSCOW, Jan. 1 -- Premier Aleksei N. Kosygin was quoted today as having said that the Soviet Union would carry out an "active policy of peace and relaxation of international tension" in 1965.
Mayor Wagner rejected a request by two welfare unions yesterday to intervene in their contract dispute with the city to head off a strike threatened for Monday.
DETROIT, Jan. 1 -- A ban on racial discrimination in Roman Catholic church and school construction jobs went into effect in Michigan today.
PARIS, Jan. 1 -- President de Gaulle's radio and television speech to the French people last night provoked some unfriendly comments in the press today.

SO far as exhibitions are concerned the old year bows out in a meager fashion, all those engaged in the art world bracing themselves for the tidal wave of shows engulfing the local scene early next week.

The confidence, at times approaching arrogance, that Communist Chinese Premier Chou En-lai exhibited in his report to the National People's Congress in Peking is understandable. China has made a series of significant gains this past year. Psychologically, Peking's explosion of a relatively advanced type of atomic bomb has probably been most important. It was a feat rivaled in impact only by the implicit triumph the Chinese scored when Nikita Khrushchev fell from power in Moscow.

LANSING, Mich., Jan. 1 -- Gov. George Romney, bidding for cooperation from Michigan's first Democratic Legislature in 30 years, called today for an end to political partisanship in order to move the state in "new directions for the future."
A Democratic resolution censuring State Senator John J. Marchi for his critical report on Mobilization for Youth is scheduled for early introduction before the Legislature.
MINEOLA, L.I., Jan. 1 -- County Executive Eugene H. Nickerson of Nassau warned in an inaugural address today that the nation is in "grave danger of losing its capacity to discriminate."

COLORADO SPRINGS, Jan. 2 (UPI) -- The United States Ski Association announced today the names of 13 skiers chosen to the American preliminary squad to compete in the International Alpine team races at Vail, Colo., March 13 to 15.
A primary objective in the battle of materials has been the automobile, a big-volume item that represents one of the mainstays of the American economy.
WATERTOWN, N.Y., Jan. 2 -- A motive in the New Year's Eve murder of two men and a woman near here was sought today by the state police.

QUITE the most pleasant television news at the year's end was the presentation of the Royal Ballet in ideal evening time on the network of the Columbia Broadcasting System. Not only that, but upward of 11 million people tuned in Margot Fonteyn and Rudolph Nureyev in "Los Sylphides" and shared in the beauty of the art of the dance.

SAN JUAN, P.R., Jan. 2 -- Roberto Sanchez Vilella, civil engineer-politician committed to the idea of permanent union with the United States, became the Governor of "the free associated state" of Puerto Rico today.

FRANCE'S Jean Anouilh, Britain's Peter Glenville and Hollywood's Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer will, at least partially, illustrate the one-world moviemaking concept by joining forces on a feature film. Last week, it was learned that the English director and the noted French playwright, who teamed their talents for "Becket," already are at work on the first subject in a trio of films to be produced by Mr. Glenville's Maximilian Productions in association with M-G-M.

The New York Rovers have their sights on third place in the Eastern Hockey League's Northern Division. In order to move up into that spot they will have to beat the Johnstown Jets when they meet at Madison Square Garden this afternoon at 2:30.

The airlines, long out of fashion on Wall Street, have once again come back in style with investment houses -- and for a very simple reason. The carriers' profits are soaring, partly because the economics of jet transportation have begun to turn in their favor, partly because they are cultivating the travel market as never before.

I have no idea what is the real cause of the dispute over the Lincoln Center repertory theater. I am sure that whatever it is, it can be settled equitably by the parties. The first snow of the new year, mixed with a freezing rain, produced hazardous driving conditions and some transportation delays in the metropolitan area yesterday.

The Ford Foundation announced yesterday that it had given more than $2 billion in its support of education, culture and community welfare since it started making grants in 1936.

AS an image added to a montage of good works in the entertainment arts, Richard Schickel's "Movies" is proof of dedication and versatility. He is the author of "The World of Carnegie Hall," printed just before that fortress of the fugue was saved from demolition, and "The Stars," a text-and-picture paean to the screen's once crowded, shining galaxy.

GRANTED that a lot has been written, early and late about the abolitionists, this book nevertheless has something new and vital and relevant to say on the subject. The fact is that James McPherson, who teaches history at Princeton, has carried his thorough investigation beyond the conventional limits into an important and heretofore unexplored period of abolitionist history.
A FEW day ago we got a call from Dr. Flabbergast, who sounded terribly excited. We dropped everything and rushed over to see the great man.

PORT WASHINGTON, L.I., Jan. 2 -- "Do you really want to sail?" the girl crewman asked her male skipper today as snow swirled down into the empty swimming pool on the lawn of the Manhasset Bay Yacht Club.

WASHINGTON, Jan 2 -- In talking privately about his education program the other day, President Johnson said he hoped to raise the Federal Government's contribution from a high of $700 million under President Kennedy to over $3 billion in the coming year.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 2 -- The Negro - liberal challenge to Mississippi's election laws will reach a high point on Monday.
HONG KONG, Jan. 2 -- Communist China announced tonight that its air force shot down a pilotless United States high-altitude reconnaissance plane today.

PERHAPS no other New York musical organization has taken -- or had to take -- such a serious midseason inventory this year as the Festival Orchestra Society. This is the group that planned an inaugural subscription season of 40 concerts, 20 of them in Carnegie Hall on Wednesday nights, the other 20 being repetitions in Philharmonic Hall on Friday nights.

THE White House is a tough assignment these days for a newsman, especially those who do most of their exercising at the Press Club bar. But some reporters who have been lost too often in the crush that always surrounds the peripatetic President have finally found the answer: stand next to Nancy Dickerson.

Joe Namath, the 21-year-old son of a steelworker who once shined shoes to help keep the family cupboard stocked, was rated by New York Jet scouts as the "best prospect since Sammy Baugh, Jet coach Weeb Ewbank said yesterday.

SACRAMENTO, Calif., Jan. 2 (UPI) -- If one speaks a foreign language, has been to college and wants to work with young minds, he can come to California. The public schools here need thousands of teachers for a new program designed to give all youngsters the ability to speak a foreign language.
In 1964 the number of disabled Americans rehabilitated into employment by the state-Federal vocational rehabilitation program reached a new high for the ninth consecutive year.

AS usual, the New York Film Critics stuck pretty close to the script in performing their annual ritual of picking the "bests" of 1964. They named a respectable number of the candidates that everyone expected them to, and then they voted a couple of surprises, just to prove themselves an independent group.
MIAMI, Jan. 2 -- In a Hollywood setting of grinding cameras and high-powered lights, Joe Namath was presented today as a member of the New York Jets of the American Football League.

THE past year was a record-breaking one for the world's airlines, and the early forecast is that 1965 will be even better. According to figures released last week by the International Civil Aviation Organization, whose members represent 107 countries, 156 million people flew more than 107 billion miles on domestic and international flights in 1964.

Mrs. John Davis Lodge, chairman of the 15th annual Animal Kingdom Ball, has named the members of the various committees for the event, to be held on Jan. 21 at the Sheraton-East. I CAN'T think of a happier harbinger of a new season than a new novel by Ruth Moore. A move developed in the City Council yesterday to request a state inquiry into the Port of New York, the Triborough Bridge and Tunnel and New York City Transit Authorities.

The Texas Eastern Transmission Corporation has a new president to lead its 1965 operations. He is Baxter D. Goodrich, 51 years old, a man whose career started with the company in 1947, the year of its founding.
The Federal Reserve Board reported the following percentage changes in department store sales by cities. This report, usually published on Sunday, had been delayed because of the New Year holiday.

ALBANY, Jan. 4 -- Assemblyman Stanley Steingut issued his own "State of the State" message this afternoon, 48 hours before Governor Rockefeller was to deliver the official message. The Brooklyn legislator, who appears all but certain of election as Speaker of the Assembly when the Legislature convenes here on Wednesday, proposed what he called a "minimum program" to correct the failures of New York State.
LONDON, Jan. 4 -- The Labor Government's first test at the polls since its victory last October got under way today, and the racial issue was quickly injected into the campaign.
DETROIT, Jan. 4 (AP) -- The United States auto industry closed the books last week on its second biggest auto-building year and immediately set out to write a new record in 1965.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 4 -- Will the "Ev and Charlie show" be replaced by an "Ev and Gerry" show?
LONDON, Jan. 4 -- Foreign exchange and gold markets here took the news calmly that France is converting extra dollar reserves into gold.
DETROIT, Jan. 4 (UPI) -- Al Kaline signed his 1965 contract today with the Detroit Tigers and took what he called "a considerable pay cut."

LONDON, Jan. 4 (Reuters) -- Leaders of the giant Transport and General Workers Union tonight appealed to dockers to end a ban on weekend work in an effort to clear the backlog of exports at the Port of London.

Field Marshal Ayub Khan and the ruling Moslem League have won by a large margin in Pakistan's election. Their victory should clear the way for five years of settled government. It may seem strange to Westerners to see a nation vote for a virtual dictatorship over the possibility of internal liberty and parliamentary democracy -- which was what the rival candidate, Miss Jinnah, offered -- but this was understandable in Pakistan.

ISTANBUL, Turkey, Jan. 4 -- A Soviet parliamentary delegation headed by Nikolai V. Podgorny, a member of the Presidium of the Supreme Soviet, arrived in Ankara today.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 4 (AP) -- The Republican National Chairman, Dean Burch, said today that it was time for the Republican party to "put away the switchblades and take out the Band-Aids" in a drive for party unity.
ATLANTA, Jan. 4 -- Officials at six of the seven schools that lost to Georgia on the football field this season have declined Georgia's offer to forfeit its victories.

FAIRFIELD, Conn., Jan. 4 -- The undefeated Providence College basketball team scored its ninth victory tonight when it downed Fairfield University, 72-65, behind the all-around play of a sophomore, Jim Walker.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 4 -- The welfare and retirement fund of the United Mine Workers of America raised pension benefits of soft-coal miners today to $85 a month and lowered the retirement age from 60 to 55. The action was taken by the fund trustees.
SOUTHOLD, L.I., Jan. 4 -- A nondescript fleet of 40 scallop boats worked slowly through the cold waters of Little Peconic Bay here today.

Anna Moffo, beautiful as ever, made her first appearance this season with the Metropolitan Opera last night, singing the title role of Donizetti's "Lucia di Lammermoor." Opposite her, Carlo Bergonzi sang his season's first Edgardo.

TRURO, Mass., Jan. 4 -- A group of determined Cape Codders was assured in writing today that its plans for the site of a medical center would be discussed personally by the director of the National Park Service two weeks hence.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 4 -- President Johnson expressed the hope tonight that the new leaders of the Soviet Union could visit the United States and that they and American leaders could exchange television appearances in their respective countries.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 4 Robert F. Kennedy took his seat in the Senate today -- in the very back row.

MILWAUKEE, Jan. 4 -- The Social Development Commission of Greater Milwaukee approved today a plan for birth-control clinics. The plan had received wide attention and aroused opposition from some Milwaukee Catholics.

I regret that The Times in its Dec. 24 editorial entitled "State Aid to Students" brought its considerable influence to bear in support of proposals to remove the instate requirement and permit out-of-state use of Regents scholarships.

TOKYO, Jan. 4 -- Japan National Railways plans to cut the running time for its express trains on the New Tokaido Line between Tokyo and Osaka to three hours in October. At present the fastest trains cover the 320-mile distance in four hours.
LOS ANGELES, Jan. 4 -- Barry Goldwater has changed jobs from Senator to syndicated newspaper columnist with a comradely bow to the "pundits" with whom he recently was unhappy.
In front of the hearing room at the city's Department of Licenses yesterday, a glass box filled with fluttering Ping-Pong balls was commanding the attention of 14 men.
OSWESTRY, England, Jan. 4 (Reuters) -- A 19-year-old girl who has had six inches cut from her legs may have her arms shortened as well, a hospital spokesman said today.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 4 (AP) -- The Defense Department identified today an Army sergeant killed in action and a Marine captain, the son of a Brooklyn man, missing in South Vietnam.
LONDON, Jan. 4 -- T.S. Eliot, the quiet, gray figure who gave new meaning to English-language poetry, died today at his home in London. He was 76 years old.
YELLOW SPRINGS, Ohio, Jan. 4 (AP) -- Six Antioch College students left today for the South to work for civil rights groups and college credit.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 4 -- Labor Secretary W. Willard Wirtz today appointed Cecil R. Forster the director of Neighborhood Youth Corps activities in the northeast region.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 4 -- The United Nations' New Year opened with the General Assembly in full flight from Article 19 of the Charter; with another irresponsible resolution spread on the record of the Security Council; and under the threat of withdrawal by a member, Indonesia, which the U.N. has encouraged to rely on bullying as the tactic that succeeds.

MONTGOMERY, Ala., Jan. 4 (AP) -- Fourteen Alabama lawyers, including one of three Republican members of the Legislature, have surrendered their licenses after an Alabama Bar Association investigation into quickie divorces.

A series of four lectures for young men and women on the "Psychoanalytic Approach to Problems of Young Adulthood" will begin Thursday at 8:30 P.M. and continue on Thursday evenings through Jan. 28 at the 92d Street Young Men's and Young Women's Hebrew Association. Discussion will follow the lectures.

The National Labor Relations Board ordered a divided jurisdiction yesterday between New York Mailers Union No. 6 and the Newspaper Guild of New York, Local 3, in work related to a machine for addressing newspaper wrappers at The New York Times.

Mr. Ford, a 51-year-old Yale Law School graduate who is from Grand Rapids, Mich., moved in to the job of House minority leader today on a wave of discontent over the Republican party's losing proclivities.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 4 -- Oddly enough, it has taken the British those most amateur of all sportsmen, to make the definitive film on the corrupting influence of professional sports.

YONKERS, Jan. 4 -- Thomas A. Brogan, Yonkers contractor and a power in party politics here for a half century, resigned unexpectedly last night as Democratic city chairman. The burly, white-haired, 82-year-old leader had been chairman since 1959 and earlier had for many years directed the party's fortunes from behind the scenes.

SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 4 (UPI) -- A high-altitude jet stream brought more rain and snow to the flood-ravaged Far West today. The Weather Bureau indicated no letup was in sight for the next five days.
BERKELEY, Calif., Jan. 4 -- Classes resumed quietly at the University of California today, but a tension existed that could erupt into further civil disobedience.
COLOMBO, Ceylon, Jan. 3 -- A fairly straightforward fight between left and right is predicted by political analysts here for Ceylon's general elections March 22.
CHICAGO, Jan. 4 (UPI) -- Railroad and union negotiators broke off new talks in a strike-threatening wage dispute today after less than two hours.

LONDON, Tuesday, Jan. 5 (Reuters) -- The Foreign Office announced early today the appointment of Sir Patrick Dean as Ambassador to the United States. Sir Patrick will succeed Lord Harlech in the post. [The expected appointment was reported in a dispatch to The New York Times last week.]

ALBANY, Jan. 4 -- The proposed Huntington Hartford pavilion in New York City's Central Park was attacked here today as "a place to watch the girls go by" and defended as a spot from which to study the beauties of nature.

Frances Steloff, proprietor of the Gotham Book Mart, is busy these days selling a book that tells about her 58 years of selling books. Last night she halted this profitable activity to enjoy a champagne party attended by literary people who buy her books and write some of the books she sells.

United States Attorney Robert M. Morgenthau has requested the State Supreme Court to dismiss a motion that seeks to cite Mahmoud Foroughi, the Iranian Ambassador, for contempt for allegedly disregarding a subpoena in a creditor's suit.

President Johnson's State of the Union message is a broad-gauged and progressive statement of the national interest. LAGOS, Nigeria, Jan. 4 -- President Nnamdi Azikiwe said tonight that he would appoint a new government headed by Prime Minister Sir Abubakar Tafawa Balewa under a compromise solution of the election crisis, which has threatened to break up Nigeria's federation.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 4 (AP) -- Col. John H. Glenn Jr. retired from the Marine Corps today. He declared that he was 100 per cent fit and denied reports that a bathroom fall in which he was injured had been an after effect of his experience as an astronaut.

Rudolf Nureyev will dance with the National Ballet of Canada in Toronto for the first time tonight when he replaces Erik Bruhn in a performance of "La Sylphide." Mr. Bruhn, who staged the 132-year-old ballet by August Bournonville for the Canadian company, suffered a knee injury in a performance of the work given on New Year's Day.

Harry Gallatin was a New York Knickerbocker again yesterday for the first time in eight years. The memory of his nine seasons as a star player with the club burned through his perfunctory remarks to the team.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 4 -- The Rumanian Government initialed preliminary agreements with two American corporations last month for the construction of a synthetic rubber plant and a catalytic petroleum cracking unit in Rumania.

HARTFORD, Jan. 5 -- The Governor's colorful Foot Guard and the Foot Guard band, which trace their history to Colonial days, need $25,000 to finance their participation in President Johnson's inaugural parade in Washington on Jan. 20.
Federal investigators have identified 1,500 members of five underworld "families" in a national network of organized crime. United States Attorney Robert M. Morgenthau estimated here yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 5 -- Democrats fashioned new leverage for passage of Administration bills today by increasing their representation on all legislative committees in the House.

PEKING, Jan. 5 (Reuters) -- Three ministers removed from their posts in the Chinese Communist Government announced yesterday were among 22 vice chairmen elected by the People's Political Consultative Conference today at the end of its annual meeting.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 5 -- The House leadership struggle that deposed Representative Charles A. Halleck of Indiana has reshuffled political positions in New York State's Republican Congressional delegation.
COLOMBO, Ceylon, Jan. 3 -- Ceylon's 15,000 yellow-robed monks, the guardians and teachers of Buddhism are streaming back into political life eight years after having withdrawn from it.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 5 -- President Johnson's determination to ask Congress for a Cabinet-level department of housing and urban development will lead him over legislative and political terrain that his predecessor found thoroughly booby-trapped two years ago.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 5 -- President Johnson's travels this year may include visits to four countries in Western Europe and at least three in South America, according to present indications.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 5 -- The New York City Welfare Department got about $1.2 million of Federal assistance to which it was not entitled in 1957-61, the Controller General reported today.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 5 (AP) -- The National Cancer Institute is starting a study to determine if viruslike particles found in milk are a link to leukemia in humans or cows and other domesticated animals.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 5 (AP) -- Senator Harry F. Byrd, Democrat of Virginia, urged President Johnson today to "exert every effort to get the country out of the red."

IT was a little over four years ago that Joan Sutherland made her American debut. On Nov. 17, 1960, she sang the title role of Handel's "Alcina" in Dallas. The opera had not previously been heard in this country, nor has it been since the Dallas performances.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 5 -- Supporters of a program of medical care for the aged are predicting quick approval of the long-stalled legislation, possibly as early as Easter.

Radio station WMCA asked a Federal Court yesterday to declare unconstitutional all four reapportionment plans approved by the Republican-controlled lame-duck session of the State Legislature last month.
KUALA LUMPUR, Malaysia, Jan. 5 (AP) -- Malaysia banned nighttime ship movements in territorial waters off the southern tip of the Malayan mainland today, fearing new Indonesian guerrilla raids.
The National Association for the Advancement of Colored People has completed its selection of new members for its board of directors.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 5 -- President Johnson surprised much of Washington with the scope of his legislative program but White House sources contended today that it was both a manageable package and art "open door" for more to follow.

Fifty-one per cent of the drivers and 30 per cent of the pedestrians over 15 years of age who died within 24 hours of being involved in traffic accidents here in 1964 were drunk at the time of the accidents, the Police Department said yesterday.

BONN, Jan. 5 -- Former Chancellor Konrad Adenauer celebrated today his 89th birthday, his second since leaving office in the fall of 1963. He appeared as untiring and energetic as ever in his long public career.

NEWINGTON, Conn., Jan. 5 (AP) -- Thirty-five bank-deposit bags, bearing the name of the Braintree, Mass., bank that was robbed of more than $50,000 yesterday, were found today in the parking lot of a restaurant on the Berling Turnpike.
ROME, Jan. 5 -- The world's Roman Catholic hierarchy will reassemble in Rome on Sept. 14 for the fourth and final session of Ecumenical Council Vatican II.
LONDON, Jan. 5 (AP) -- Tough-looking prisoners in British jails are being given new faces to help them make new starts in life.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 5 -- A plan for the replacement of an ailing President appeared certain today of early Senate and House consideration. The plan, which also calls for keeping the Vice-Presidency filled, is expected to have President Johnson's active support.

M'SILA, Algeria, Jan. 5 -- President Ahmed Ben Bella sent two Cabinet ministers to this earthquake-shaken town today, four days after the first tremors killed two persons and forced thousands to flee.

COLUMBIA, S.C., Jan. 5 (UPI) -- Representative Albert W. Watson, who was stripped of his seniority by House Democrats for supporting Barry Goldwater in the Presidential election, was welcomed today by a score of admirers when he came home to decide his political future.
Three of the seven Brooklyn-Staten Island ferryboats, which stopped running after the Verrazano-Narrows bridge opened, will be auctioned by the city next week.

MIAMI, Jan. 5 (UPI) -- A former paratrooper who was swept overboard from a sloop in the Atlantic managed to stay afloat for 18 hours without a life jacket before he was rescued today, dazed and barely paddling.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, Jan. 5 -- The United States tried today to clarify for Vietnam its attitude toward Vietnamese events since Dec. 20.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 5 -- Senator J.W. Fulbright, chairman of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee, suggested today that consideration should be given to cutting off aid to countries that failed to prevent mob attacks on United States libraries.

BUENOS AIRES, Jan. 5 -- Shouting students forced five Peronist leaders today to cancel news conference, called to announce further attempts to bring Juan D. Peron, the former dictator, back to Argentina.

MONTGOMERY, Ala., Jan. 5 Gov. George C. Wallace, who ran in several Presidential primaries last year as a conservative, is now busy putting through the most liberal spending program in Alabama's history.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 5 (AP) -- The Federal Welfare Department announced today it had called on all the states to improve their public welfare programs as a major step in what President Johnson calls his war on poverty.
ADEN, Jan. 5 (AP) -- A Government shake-up in Yemen followed the return of President Abdullah al-Salal from a visit to Cairo, according to a broadcast tonight.
ELIZABETH, N.J., Jan. 5 -- A 19-year-old youth was arrested today after allegedly shooting a rookie patrolman and shouting, "I've shot a cop -- hooray!"

ALBANY, Jan. 5 -- The Democrats failed again tonight to resolve their struggle over legislative leadership.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 5 -- Forty-seven state legislatures are meeting this year to grapple with issues as varied as the national landscape.
EDMONTON, Alberta, Jan. 5 (Canadian Press) -- Brutal cold, suffocating snow drifts and birds of prey are sharply reducing western Canada's game bird population.

Mort Sahl, the monologist, has been fined $1,000 by his union, Actors Equity, for his unauthorized absence last September from rehearsals of "The Sign in Sidney Brustein's Window." The charges were brought against him by Robert D'Lugoff, Robert Nemiroff and J.I. Jahre, producers of the Lorraine Hansberry drama, who engaged Gabriel Dell to replace Mr. Sahl.
BONN, Jan. 7 -- A political wrangle is delaying agreement on direct passenger flights between Moscow and Frankfurt.

Refurbishing has been completed on three old houses occupied by the Henry Street Settlement at 263, 265 and 267 Henry Street on the lower East Side. The houses have been designated as landmarks worthy of preservation by the city's Landmarks Preservation Commission.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 7 (AP) -- President Johnson named Maj. Gen. William F. Cassidy today to be the new chief of the Army Engineers.

MANILA, Jan. 7 -- Indonesian efforts to drive a wedge between the Philippines and the United States have been one of a series of developments that have severely damaged the once promising friendship of Manila and Jakarta.

AT least three of the nine top ski school teachers who went to the International Ski Instructors Congress that starts today in Badgastein, Austria, picked an opportune time. Herb Schneider and Paul Valar, who head the ski school at Mount Cranmore and Cannon Mountain in New Hampshire respectively, and Barry Bryant of Madonna Mountain at Jeffersonville, Vt., will help demonstrate the newly developed American technique.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 7 (AP) -- The Air Force announced today that it would disband 155 more Air Force Reserve units by April -- probably a preliminary step toward merging the remaining Air Force Reserve units into the Air National Guard.

District Attorney Frank S. Hogan plans to recommend a prison sentence of one to two years for three suspects accused of the American Museum of Natural History burglary if they plead guilty -- and if the gems are returned.
PARIS, Jan. 7 -- France announced tonight the first two steps in implementing President de Gaulle's decision to cut back her dollar reserves in favor of gold.
The Queens County Republican Committee acceded to the party's state leadership last night and voted to postpone the election of a county leader.

LONDON -- At Harry Hall's on Regent Street, where the smell of leather is pervasive and conversations are thick with the clipped accents of horsy aristocrats, Douglas Bedford, who manages the store, ran his finger over an elegant black riding boot fashioned for a foreign duchess.

WHEN he puts his imagination and flair for fantasy to better use. Ben Kerner may write an arresting play. "All Women Are One," which arrived last night at the Gate Theater, is windy and pretentious in its handling of fancy and ponderous in making its point.

LOS ANGELES, Jan. 7 (UPI) -- Willie Naulls and Sam Jones powered Boston to a 29-6 lead in the opening five and a half minutes of play and the Celtics hung on to defeat the Los Angeles Lakers, 112 -- 104, tonight for their 10th straight National Basketball Association victory.
HOUSTON, Tex., Jan. 7 -There is not as much leeway in the moon-program schedule as there was a year ago.
TRENTON, Jan. 7 -- Gov. Richard J. Hughes reported today the opening of the most concerted drive in New Jersey's history to induce New York to raise its minimum drinking age from 18 to 21.

Rod Seiling, the New York Rangers' outstanding rookie defenseman, will miss the Blues' next two games because of an injury to his left shoulder during the Rangers' 5-2 victory over the Boston Bruins Wednesday night at Madison Square Garden.
DETROIT, Jan. 7 -- The Chrysler Corporation announced today that it had agreed to purchase the outboard-engine business of the West Bend Company.

DARIEN, Conn., Jan. 7 -An ordinance prohibiting the consumption of liquor by minors on public property has been approved by the Board of Selectmen. The law is expected to be adopted by the Representative Town Meeting at its March session.
BAY SHORE, L.I., Jan. 7 -Who is Robert Glenn Thompson?

A husky 29-year-old former Air Force enlisted man who had served in West Berlin was arrested yesterday and charged with having been a spy for the Soviet Union in this country and abroad for six years.

WEST POINT, Miss., Jan. 7 -- Four civil rights workers and six local Negro teen-agers were arrested here last night on a charge of disturbing the peace after they had demonstrated at the city jail. They were protesting the arrest yesterday of a Negro high school student.

FREEPORT, Grand Bahamas, Jan. 7 (AP) -- Nigel Morris, Police Commissioner of the Bahamas, sealed off a section of the Atlantic today where a sunken Spanish galleon full of gold and silver is reported to lie.
A 41-FOOT motor yacht from Canada will start fighting for elbow room in an East Side parking lot today, and a "revolutionary" 35-foot hydrofoil from Philadelphia will dock at a West Side marina.
Two publishers, each claiming the right to the best-selling novel "Candy," are racing to bring paperback editions to the market, and each is challenging the other through legal proceedings.

A Negro real estate broker who posted the words "Bigot's List" on the wall of his office above a list of Queens property owners opposed to blockbusting has had his broker's license suspended for 90 days.

Leading bankers and economists here expressed their support yesterday for any plan that President Johnson might have to ask Congress to remove part of the gold backing behind the nation's money supply.
ANYONE who doubts that fashion mannequins are charter members of the new international set has not met Mieko Takashima Wikstrom, who arrived from Stockholm Wednesday evening.
General Marshall's remark about postwar Europe is applicable to the New Haven Railroad. "The patient sinks while the doctors deliberate."

The Great Atlantic and Pacific Tea Company, Inc., continued to show improvement in the 12 weeks ended Nov. 28 and, as a result, made a sharp recovery in earnings for the 39 weeks ended on that date, the report showed yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 7 -- Six Senators from four states spent their lunch-hour today discussing ways to save the New Haven Railroad.
BOSTON, Jan. 7 -- Former Gov. John A. Volpe returned to office today for the last two-year term for a Massachusetts chief executive. Beginning in 1967, the term will be four years.
ROME, Jan. 7 -- Pope Paul VI spoke fervently and spontaneously today of "the uneasiness of our heart" caused by menaces to world peace.
For the first time since the day before Christmas, almost all Treasury bond prices declined yesterday.

CHICAGO, Jan. 7 (AP) -Directors of the Greyhound Corporation adopted today a plan to buy the Travelers Express Company, Minneapolis, to put the bus company into the business of selling traveler's checks through its 5,000 agencies.

MIAMI, Jan. 7 -- Allan Dale Kuhn, four New York detectives and an assistant district attorney went into hiding today in their effort to recover the 24 gems stolen from the American Museum of Natural History in New York.
The Verrazano-Narrows Bridge has carried 1,860,000 vehicles that have paid nearly a million dollars in tolls since the bridge was opened on Nov. 21.
BETHLEHEM, Pa., Jan. 7 (UPI) -- St. Joseph's College bounced back into the victory column tonight by walloping Lehigh University, 85 -- 55, in the Engineers' Grace Hall.
STOCKHOLM, Jan. 7 (Reuters) -- Ingmar Bergman plans to take Stockholm's Royal Dramatic Theater Company on tour to New York, London and Paris in the spring of next year.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 7 -- Intercity truck tonnage and loadings of rail freight both declined last week from the volume handled in the corresponding week a year earlier, it was announced today.
KUALA LUMPUR, Malaysia, Jan. 7 -- The British aircraft carrier Eagle was en route to Southeast Asian waters today as the limited build-up of British military strength in this area continued.
W.R. Grace Co. announced plans yesterday to offer to holders of its common stock $84 million of convertible debentures.

There was a hint yesterday that Anthony (Tino) DeAngelis, the kingpin in the $150 million soybean oil swindle, may be planning to plead guilty to at least part of a 19 -count indictment handed down against him last March.
KINGSTON, R.I., Jan. 7 (AP) Rhode Island flashed a balanced scoring attack and dominated the backboards tonight in rolling to a 98-75 basketball victory over Holy Cross.

CAIRO, Jan. 7 (UPI) -- The United Arab Republic has provided the United States Embassy with a rent-free building to serve as a temporary site for the John F. Kennedy Memorial Library, which was destroyed by fire during a riot last November, the embassy said today.

BEVERLY, Mass., Jan. 7 (UPI) -- Former Ambassador Henry Cabot Lodge said tonight that withdrawal from war-torn South Vietnam would be "the most dangerous and imprudent" action the United States could take.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 7 -- President Johnson has at least lifted the level of political discussion here in the last few days. A month ago the capital was talking primarily about the future of Dean Burch, scarcely a world-shaking topic, but now it is talking a little more about the future of the human race.

Three major locals of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters announced pension increases yesterday that will bring the incomes of members retiring in the future to $175 a month exclusive of Social Security.

ABBEYLEIX, Ireland, Friday, Jan. 8 -- An explosion last night that was attributed by the police to extremist saboteurs rocked the Irish manor house where Princess Margaret and her husband, the Earl of Snowden, are vacationing.
A wide-ranging campaign against fraudulent art works is being developed by a 19-member committee of the Association of the Bar of the City of New York.
Wall Street bulls held the initiative in the stock market again yesterday, stretching the string of advances to three.
HONOLULU, Jan. 7 (UPI) -Forty-nine of the nation's best collegiate football seniors were pronounced fit today for the 19th annual Hula Bowl game at Honolulu Stadium tomorrow night.
A donor of $250 to the Neediest Cases Fund yesterday sent a note that explained not only his reason for giving but also how the money had become available.
MINEOLA, L.I., Jan. 7 -Mrs. Fred S. Haggerson has resigned as chairman of the Long Island Arts Center music committee.
The Davidson Wildcats, ranked among the top 10 of the nation's basketball teams, rallied in the second half last night to defeat New York University, 82 -- 73, at Madison Square Garden.
New York City banks borrowed unusually large sums from other banks in the week Reserve Bank of New York reported yesterday.

Prices for gold shares advanced sharply in an otherwise spotty session yesterday on the London Stock Exchange. Overall, prices registered little change.

JERUSALEM (Israeli Sector) -- To look at the Judean hills is to wonder that they have supported populations for thousands of years.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 7 -- The National Labor Relations Board today reaffirmed its policy of permitting union bargaining units at department stores of less than storewide scope.
The Morgan Guaranty Trust Company reported yesterday that its net operating earnings rose by 11 per cent in 1964 to a record $54,573,524, or $6.58 a share.

Two men who began their careers with the Allis-Chalmers Manufacturing Company as salesmen moved up to top positions with the company yesterday. Directors of the large farm-equipment manufacturer elected Robert S. Stevenson as chairman and chief executive officer.
Salary increases of $5,000 a year were granted by Mayor Wagner yesterday to George A. Wallace, director of probation, and Seymour N. Siegel, director of the Municipal Broadcasting System.

BOSTON, Jan. 7 (UPI) -- The Boston Bruins scored two goals in each of the first two periods tonight and went on to score a a 5-2 victory over the Detroit Wings. Gordie Howe of Detroit scored twice in the final period.

The New York City Youth Board's method for predicting which children will become delinquents was challenged yesterday as "questionable" in its claims of accuracy and "potentially dangerous" to children.

A sharp price rise in the stock of Syntex Corporation was a feature of a generally stronger market yesterday on the American Stock Exchange.

With the early noon Times Square crowds passing by, two porters from the 46th Street Theater were kidnapped yesterday after leaving the Chemical Bank New York Trust Company branch at 1501 Broadway with a $6,700 payroll.

Striking welfare workers rejected last night a proposal submitted by a committee of the city's top labor leaders to end the five-day walkout against the Welfare Department.

Columbia's freshman basketball team set a total-point record yesterday by defeating the Seton Hall freshmen, 117 -- 88, in University Hall gymnasium. The previous high mark was 103 points, which the 1957 freshmen accomplished twice.
World sugar futures rallied sharply yesterday on the New York Coffee and Sugar Exchange in sympathy with a burst of buying in London. Price advances ranged from 0.06 cent to 0.14 cent a pound.

AMONG the 807 passengers on the liner Independence, which returned to New York last Sunday from a Mediterranean cruise, was a considerable contingent of bridge players. A pioneer in the development of the jet engine, Sir Frank Whittle, has been named to receive the Goddard Award, given by the American Institute of Aeronautics and Astronautics.

Educators, physicians and members of other professions, recognizing "the obvious uneasiness throughout the nation concerning the management of the sexual impulse," have formed an organization to help people understand and use sex meaningfully.
HARTFORD, Jan. 8 -- The New Haven Railroad announced a plan today to abandon as soon as possible all commuter service between New Rochelle, Pelham and Mount Vernon and New York City.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 8 -- The over-all level of prices in the wholesale primary markets remained unchanged at 100.8 per cent of their 1957-59 base during the two weeks ended Jan. 5, 1965, the Bureau of Labor Statistics reported today.

AKRON, Ohio, Jan. 8 (AP) -The 1920 murder conviction of LeRoy Dunlap was set aside today and the 44 years he spent as a fugitive may allow the 64-year-old grandfather to escape further punishment.

MOBILE, Ala., Jan. 8 (AP) -The North is pinning its hopes for upsetting the South and Joe Namath in tomorrow's Senior Bowl football game on a blitzing line rush and the ability of its defensive secondary to cover a receiver, Bob Hayes.

HARRISON, N.J., Jan. 8 -- The Hyatt Bearing division of the General Motors Corporation, which has been located here since 1895, will be closed in about two years and its operations transferred to the Hyatt plant in Clark Township, Union County.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 8 -- Senate Democrats, following the pattern established by Lyndon B. Johnson when he was majority leader in 1953, found at least one major committee assignment for each of their six freshmen today.
SAIGON, South Vietnam Jan. 8 (AP) -- Three United States Navy nurses wounded in the terrorist bomb explosion at the American officers' quarters on Christmas Eve were awarded Purple Hearts today.
DETROIT, Jan. 8 (AP) -- Detroit's striking hotel employes union charges seven major hotels today with unfair labor practices by locking out 1,500 union workers.
BAY SHORE, L.I., Jan. 8 -- A cleaning fluid sniffing party ended in death last night for an 18-year-old dock construction worker, according to the Suffolk County police.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 8 (AP) -- Senator Stephen M. Young, who is 76 years old, threatened today "forcefully" to throw some Senate aides out of the chamber. He said they were too noisy.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 8 -- John T. Connor, President Johnson's choice for Secretary of Commerce, will place in a trust more than $1.5 million in stock he holds in the company he headed, White House sources said today.

GRAND RAPIDS, Mich., Jan. 8 (AP) -- A ruling that religious exercises may be conducted in Jenison Public Schools was issued today by United States District Court Judge Noel P. Fox. It left to individual pupils the decision whether to take part.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 8 -- Retail sales in December rose sharply to a record monthly level, even after allowing for the usual seasonal influence of Christmas, the Commerce Department reported today.

Last night, in the first performance the company has given it at the New York State Theater, "Divertimento No. 15" (known as "Caracole" when it was created in 1952) appeared to have diminished in size and magnificence in the move to grander surroundings.

ONE of the infrequent performances of Erik Satie's "Socrate" turned up last night in Philharmonic Hall. For a while, about 15 or 20 years back, New York was getting a bit of Satie, thanks mostly to Virgil Thomson.
BONN, Jan. 8 (AP) -- Chancellor Ludwig Erhard's Government predicted today that West Germany's gross national product will increase by 5 per cent in 1965, reaching the equivalent of $108.5 billion.

Two dinner parties in celebration of recent marriages were among the social events that took place last evening before the second of the season's New York Assemblies in the grand ballroom of the Plaza.

The third mate of the American freighter Smith Voyager said here yesterday that he was under the impression he had been ordered to abandon ship by the master of the heavily listing vessel last Dec. 20.

In this book, Ralph G. Martin, author of a recent entertaining history of election campaigns, "Ballots and Bandwagons," sets out to prove it.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 8 (UPI) -- Mrs. Ethel Kennedy, wife of Senator Robert F. Kennedy of New York, arranged for a shipment of toys to Miami's Cuban exile colony for children of veterans of the 1961 Cuban invasion.

GREENWICH, Conn., Jan. 8 -- Miss Ida Ethelwyn McKinney, who died last June at the age of 93, left an estate worth nearly $13 million. Nearly two-thirds of it went to her niece, Mrs. Jean McKinney Connor, and the income from a third will go to the Oakwood School in Poughkeepsie, N.Y.

COLUMBIA, S.C., Jan. 8 (AP) -- South Carolina survived a late press by Virginia tonight and scored its first Atlantic Coast Conference basketball victory of the season, 64 -- 60.
THERE are many things that can make an expatriate homesick, some predictable, some not.

PANAMA, Jan. 8 -- President Marco Aurelio Robles appealed to the nation tonight to avoid violence tomorrow on the first anniversary of last January's anti-American rioting in which a score of Panamanians and four Americans lost their lives.

A Columbia professor who has been drafting a plan for consolidation of the city's housing code enforcement services replied yesterday to criticism that Mayor Wagner had not moved fast enough in setting up a citizens' panel to advise on the study.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 8 (UPI) -- The State Department said today that Miss Taylor was still a United States citizen although she went through a formality of renouncing her comment on any individual's income tax.
