BERLIN, Jan. 11 -- Chancellor Erhard declared today that during his meeting with General de Gaulle next week he would make no commitment to France that was unacceptable to the United States.

BEAVER MEADOW, N.Y. Jan. 11 -- The most popular game animals in this country are the rabbits and hares, and with very good reason. They are found everywhere, in one form or another, and provide sport for millions.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 11 (AP) -- The House Committee on Un-American Activities made public today testimony by a member Of the National Advisory Council of the Peace Corps who had asked for a hearing to "help clear up the records" on his past associations with groups cited as having Communist connections.

CANBERRA, Australia, Jan. 11 -- Successful though Australia's immigration program has been in building up the country's population and promoting social and economic development, many Australians wonder if it is good enough.
The latest report on cigarette smoking, awaited with considerable concern by the tobacco industry, already seems to be blowing over with no immediate major effects.
Two items in your Jan. 4 issue regarding the so-called Bryn Mawr Hotel need to be clarified.
The strike-bound Welfare Department is about to put its relief clients on the honor system.

CORAL GABLES, Fla., 11 (AP) -- B.T. Johnson's Bill Reid scored a 2 1/2-length victory today in the seventh race at Tropical Park, with Try Cash second, Mark Prince, the favorite, third and Rolling Sea fourth in a three-horse photo.

Oxford University Press will publish on March 25 "The Modern Tradition: Backgrounds of Modern Literature," edited by Richard Ellman and Charles Feidelson Jr. The book is a 968-page anthology that links statements of literary position with writings of intellectual character.
CHICAGO, Jan. 11 -- The American Medical Association was challenged today by the American Hospital Association over accrediting nursing homes throughout the country.
Ramer Industries, Inc., has announced the election as directors of Rudolph Cohen, Howard Stamer, Robert J. Haft, Bernard Fischer and Edward M. Cowett.
IOWA CITY, Iowa, Jan. 11 (UPI) -- Indiana knocked Iowa from the Big Ten basketball lead tonight, leading the Hawkeyes almost all the way in an 85-76 victory.

NASHUA, N.H., Jan. 11 -- The First Chamber Dance Quartet of New York, which performed here tonight at the Senior High School Auditorium, lost its station wagon by fire on the Maine Turnpike yesterday.

OAKDALE, L.I., Jan. 11 -- Adelphi Suffolk College will hold its first distinguished citizens award dinner Thursday. More than 1,000 persons are expected to attend the benefit at the Huntington Town House.
Waddell Reed, Inc., outlined a plan yesterday to pass along savings to the 330,000 shareholders of the United Funds group of mutual funds by cutting management fees.
Theater owners who permit children under 16 to attend films intended for adult audiences will be called before the city's Department of Licenses for a hearing soon.
TULSA, Okla., Jan. 11 (AP) -- The St. Louis Hawks, paced by Lenny Wilkens, withstood a late rally by the Philadelphia 76ers and posted a 100-90 National Basketball Association victory tonight.
DETROIT, Jan. 11 (AP) -- The three-millionth passenger car of the 1965-model run will roll off a United States assembly line this week as the industry makes up ground lost because of recent strikes.

Three elevator apartment houses, with a total of 275 units and 1,100 rooms, have been bought by Arthur Koeppel and Stanley Mohr, realty investors, through their subsidiary, the Seventh National Corporation, in a $2 million deal.
FOUND under many Christmas trees were gaily wrapped, long, slender packages that, instead of bringing happiness, will cause many family tragedies unless handled with care.

After the proposal last year for an addition to Gracie Mansion that had all the charm and suitability of a suburban garage, this year's revised design is notable for its scholarly and appropriate good taste.
The British pound rose sharply in quiet trading on the foreign exchange markets here yesterday. It closed at $2.7915, up 17 points from Friday.

A news dispatch from Milan tells us that the famed Cathedral has been completed. Time did not fly in this case, because the Italians started building the church, according to most authorities, in 1386.
RIVERHEAD, L.I., Jan. 11 -- The Boards of Supervisors of Suffolk and Nassau Counties established a bicounty planning agency today to deal with regional problems of Long Island.
Stocks made another advance on the American Stock Exchange yesterday in active trading.

The first assistant engineer of the American freighter Smith Voyager told Coast Guard investigators here yesterday that he abandoned the heavily listing vessel only after an argument with the third mate.
LONDON, Jan. 11 (AP) -- Thirty mummies found in a tomb by King Edward VII during a state visit to Egypt in 1896 may have been planted to give him the pleasure of discovering them, experts said today.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 11 -- Shaykh Muhammad Hassan, 33-year-old leader of a religious group, was sentenced to 18 months to three years in prison and fined $1,000 today for inciting the north Philadelphia riots and looting last August.

J. Raymond Jones, the leader of the New York County Democratic organization, has denied any wrongdoing before a state commission investigating possible political corruption in middle-income housing projects.
A group of white parents in Queens who have kept 140 children out of two integrated public schools since last September defied a new Board of Education ultimatum yesterday.
LONDON, Jan. 11 -- Harold Wilson and Aleksei N. Kosygin, the British and Soviet leaders who came to power about the same time last October, will exchange visits this year.

The New York Rangers have received the first dividend on their $250,000 investment in reviving the New York Rovers. Although not so tangible as 4 per cent interest from a savings bank, the dividend promises to increase in value.

MOSCOW, Jan. 11 -- Daniel Barenboim, a 22-year-old Israeli pianist, has met critical and popular acclaim in the start of a two-week Soviet tour despite the handicap of four broken piano strings in one of his two Moscow recitals.

The period of the Congress Dances in Vienna 150 years ago will be recreated at the 10th annual Viennese Opera Ball Feb. 5 at the New York Hilton. The gala, which took place during the Congress of Vienna, was a celebration by royalty of their return to their thrones at the downfall of Napoleon.

SALEM, Ore., Jan. 11 -- Political storm flags were hoisted today as Gov. Mark O. Hatfield delivered his last message to a regular opening session of the state Legislature, which meets every two years.
A total of $1,100,000 has been pledged to the Saratoga Performing Arts Center by the Rockefeller Brothers Fund and by three of the Rockefeller brothers individually.

HONG KONG, Jan. 11 -- The downfall of Premier Khrushchev and China's first nuclear explosion were "especially unfortunate" for President Johnson, according to an article in Jenmin Jih Pao, the Chinese Communist party newspaper.

The Western Union Telegraph Company reported yesterday a drop in net income for the first 11 months of 1964 and the month of November despite increased operating revenues in both Periods. The figures were disclosed in a regular report to the Federal Communications Commission so there was no further comment from the company.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Jan. 11 -- Indonesia snubbed the annual meeting of the United Nations Special Fund today but her seat in the 24-nation Governing Council of the fund was held open.
Mayor Wagner's office confirmed yesterday that the City Department of Investigation was looking into the details of a 1962 plan for the building of a marina and boatel near the Battery.

The city dug out from its biggest snowfall of the winter yesterday, experiencing some delay in trains, buses and subways, as well as some minor irritations, but suffering no major disruption in its workaday routine.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 11 -- President Johnson will request a civilian space budget slightly larger than the $5.25 billion that Congress appropriated last year, despite the holddown on Government spending, informed sources said today.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 11 -- Senator Everett McKinley Dirksen, sharing the stage with a new partner, offered the Republican party a new top-level mechanism today to avert a repetition of last year's election rout.
PARIS, Jan. 11 -- A compromise that would allow the British-French project for a supersonic jet airliner to proceed appeared possible tonight for the first time.
PARIS -- Collaboration is unthinkable to most designers in the haute couture. They go it alone. If they occasionally need help, there are anonymous assistants to provide it.

The week-old strike of Welfare Department employes is making a shambles of municipal aid to the city's most helpless citizens. Men, women and children in need of emergency assistance are exposed to the danger of being unable to get it while those who have found jobs or other means of self-support will find automated cheek-writing machines sending them relief money they no longer should have.
Mrs. Robert F. Kennedy, who had skated on the Rockefeller Center ice rink two weeks ago, gave birth to an 8-pound boy yesterday morning at Roosevelt Hospital.

OTTAWA, Jan. 11 -- Canada is facing substantial increase in its labor force, a percentage rise greater than that in any other Western industrial nation, and must provide 1.5 million more jobs by 1970, a planning agency created by the Government said today.

JEAN PHILIPPE RAMEAU was a contemporary of Bach, Handel, Couperin, Scarlatti and Vivaldi. It was the great age of the baroque, and Rameau was one of its important figures. But, unlike the others, he composed little that seems to mean much to 20th-century listeners.
The Collegiate Basketball Officials Association said yesterday it would prohibit any member from officiating a game if he was over 55 years old.
CREDIT the repertory ledger of the Association of Producing Artists at the Phoenix Theater with another distinct asset: its production of a version of "War and Peace," which opened last night.
CHICAGO, Jan. 11 -- More than a quarter of a million items used in and around the home were placed on display today at the opening of the National Manufacturers Association's semiannual show.
INDIANAPOLIS, Jan. 11 -- Roger D. Branigin, Democrat, called the Federal Government "the most potent force of social action in our lives," as he was sworn in today as Indiana's 42d Governor.
Ray C. Bliss announced yesterday he would agree to replace Dean Burch as Chairman of the Republican National Committee only if Senator Barry Goldwater sponsored the change.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 11 -- Premier Eisaku Sato of Japan arrived tonight for two days of meetings with President Johnson on problems of Asia and of United States-Japanese relations.

BOWIE, Md., Jan. 11 -- Major thoroughbred racing -- the horse player's harbinger of spring, more welcome than the first robin on the lawn or the first crocus peeping through the snow -- came to Bowie today.

LONDON, Jan. 11 -- The United States Treasury's warning to gold speculators last week that they would get their fingers burned had a calming effect on gold and foreign exchange markets in London today.
Unions representing New York's striking welfare workers started yesterday to set up an emergency fund to pay benefits to their members by the end of the week.
The election of John L. Lynch and John T. Lyons as vice presidents of the J. Henry Schroder Banking Corporation and the Schroder Trust Company was announced yesterday.
BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Jan. 11 (UPI) -- Communist Yugoslavia is expected to liberalize her laws on religion next month, the official press agency Tanyug reported today.
In an unusual corporate gesture, the Stauffer Chemical Company will hold its regular monthly directors meeting in Mexico City next week, the company is expected to announce today.
LOS ANGELES, Jan. 11 (UPI) -- Paul Harney, the 1964 winner, withstood a rally by Dan Sikes today and won the $70,000 Los Angeles open golf tournament with a 72-hole score of 276.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 11 -- President Johnson set the stage today for another "preshrunk" foreign aid request, to be made in a special message to Congress Thursday.

Iorwith Wilbur Abel, the gray-haired, deep-voiced secretary-treasurer of the United Steelworkers of America, stood before an applauding, whistling audience of steel-union members at Faneuil Hall in Boston. He had just been introduced as the "new president" of the 1,120,000-member union.
LONDON, Jan 11 -- Two powerful merchant banks are joining forces in one of the biggest financial marriages in recent years.
CHICAGO, Jan. 11 (UPI) -- The feud between the National Collegiate Athletic Association and Amateur Athletic Union flared tonight as the leaders of the two organizations exchanged charges.
Soybean futures staged a dramatic rally in late trading yesterday on the Chicago Board of Trade after a sharp break in prices earlier in the session.
JERUSALEM (Israeli Sector), Jan. 11 -- The 26th congress of the World Zionist Organization ended early today in discord and in doubt about its purpose.

Despite its record-sale attainments of last year, retailing must become more of a science and less of an art. The merchandising process, now broadly said to be 65 per cent art, 35 per cent science, must incorporate new techniques of planning, expense control and inventory selectiondff.

ALBANY, Jan. 11 -- Three ballots in the Senate and one in the Assembly failed today to resolve the leadership impasse that has kept the Democrats from organizing the Legislature. In the upper house, Senator Jack E. Bronston of Queens gained three votes, giving him a majority of the 33 Democratic Senators for the first time.

Today's hearings of the Senate Commerce Committee on confirmation of John T. Connor as Secretary of Commerce will indicate again how complex are the problems of Government ethics. Even though Mr. Connor has announced that he will follow President Johnson's example and set up an irrevocable trust to administer his business holdings, some Senators apparently question the propriety of his purchasing stock in Merck Co. after his nomination.
A woman was found fatally stabbed early yesterday in a corridor leading from the lobby of a Queens apartment building.
PARIS, Jan. 11 -- The price of gold in Paris, where the most recent gold crisis started, fell today almost as much as it rose on Friday.

EDUCATIONAL television station WNDT has made two forward steps in as many days. It has reached an agreement with the American Federation of Television and Radio Artists that will allow professional theater people to appear before the cameras of Channel 13.

Jack Paar said yesterday that he would not renew his television contract with the National Broadcasting Company when it expires in June. He said he would move to Poland Spring, Me., where he owns a television station, but he had no plans beyond that.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 11 -- At least 125,000 Americans will die this year from the effects of cigarette smoking, despite a drop in the per capita rate of consumption, it was said here today.

CHICAGO, Jan. 11 -- The Columbia Broadcasting System, which purchased the New York Yankees last fall, now wishes to own and stage a college football bowl game. C.B.S. yesterday presented the National Collegiate Athletic Association with a plan to promote the Santa Claus Bowl in Atlanta on Christmas Day of 1966.
The longshoremen's strike is costing dock workers and the city's shipping industry $1.3 million a day in direct losses alone, the New York Shipping Association estimated yesterday.
The Chase Manhattan Bank, the largest in New York, reported yesterday an 8.9 per cent rise in net operating earnings in 1964.
JACKSON, Miss., Jan, 11 -- Government attorneys presented to a Federal grand jury today the purported confessions of two of the 21 men accused in the slaying of three civil rights workers last June.

A Brooklyn man convicted four times of drunken driving was able to obtain a new license to drive because of "a serious breakdown in communications between the courts and the Department of Motor Vehicles."
Alpheus C. Beane has become a general partner in Reynolds Co. He is in charge of personnel and new business development at the brokerage firm's five branches in the New York area.
STERLING, Ohio, Jan. 11 (UPI) -- Five locomotive crewmen were killed early today in a head-on collision between two long freight trains at a crossing here.

A boycott without precedent in professional sports by 21 Negro athletes caused a sudden shift yesterday in the site of the American Football League's all-star game. Joe Foss, the league's commissioner, announced in Chicago that the game, an annual one, would be played in Houston on Saturday rather than in New Orleans, its original site.
Gold shares declined in price yesterday on the London Stock Exchange. The rest of the list remained firm and prices inched ahead.

ENSCONCED these days in a room at the Biltmore Hotel is a rather small, smartly tailored, neat-looking man with a tape measure around his neck who is wondering what is in store for him in the course of this visit.
SPRINGFIELD, Ill., Jan. 11 -- Gov. Otto Kerner was inaugurated today for a second four-year term.
Ten men involved in "a whole Pandora's box of crime," according to Assistant District Attorney Irving P. Seidman, appeared before the Brooklyn grand jury investigating gambling yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 11 -- The story about Melina Mercouri and Aristotle Onassis smashing $600 worth of dishes in an Athenian restaurant the other night raises questions about President Johnson's vision of the Great Society.
The appointment of Clarence E. Larson as president of the nuclear division of the Union Carbide Corporation was announced yesterday by Birny Mason Jr., president of the giant producer of chemicals.
The Government is winning its criminal actions in five indictments against steel industry companies, but the victory is not considered complete.

International travelers were clocked here at the rate of more than 17,000 a day and duty collections were almost $2 million a day in 1964, making the year the port's busiest in travel and trade. A total of 6,294,716 international travelers and $701 million in customs collections were recorded in the year.

TULSA, Okla., Jan. 11 (AP) A medical missionary, a pilot, a newspaper editor and a 21-year-old adventurer-author are among the 10 outstanding young men of 1964 named today by the United States Junior Chamber of Commerce.

SOUTHAMPTON, England, Jan. 11 (Reuters) -- Authorities today ordered an inquest into the death of Fred Fleet, a lookout on the liner Titanic, who hanged himself yesterday two weeks after his wife's death.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, Tuesday, Jan. 12 -- A general strike called by Buddhist opponents of the South Vietnamese Government disrupted major cities in central Vietnam yesterday.
In two of C.L. Sulzberger's columns [Dec. 28 and 30] on General de Gaulle's views on NATO, he refers to the North Atlantic Treaty as expiring in 1969.

The shipworkers of the Brooklyn Navy Yard used facts and figures yesterday, rather than passionate appeals, in a 13th-hour attempt to persuade the Defense Department to reverse its decision to close the yard.

The legality of the Shubert box-office outlets in Macy's department stores, a point challenged by the Metropolitan Theater Ticket Agents Guild, is to be determined at a hearing before License Commissioner Joseph DiCarlo.

Teen-agers in the Henry Street Settlement's theater group will present "Oklahoma!" Friday evening at the settlement's playhouse at 466 Grand Street. Proceeds will go to the settlement's program for encouraging children in the performing arts.

The conclusion of a $200 million transaction in which Marine Transport Lines will purchase most of the tanker and dry-cargo fleet of Stavros Niarchos will take "at least another 60 days," a well-informed source said yesterday.
CHICAGO, Jan. 11 (UPI) -- The Illinois Midcontinent Life Insurance Company has sued its former interim president and two former vice presidents for $500,000.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 11 -- The late Col. Stephen Bonsal, who knew everyone of consequence the world over in his long career as a newspaper correspondent and a Foreign Service officer, used to tell of an Oriental governing device which bears some resemblance to the new Republican Coordinating Committee.
Cassius Clay, doubtful that his return match with Sonny Liston will come off, has offered a heavyweight title fight to George Chuvalo if the Canadian beats Floyd Paterson.

Much of Harry Karlin's final month before retirement after 45 years at City College has been spent talking about his past foibles, folly and moments of greatness. Mostly he talks about sports, for he has spent most of his life coaching.
JAKARTA, Indonesia, Jan. 11 -- Letters from President Sukarno explaining Indonesia's withdrawal from the United Nations will be taken to leaders of African and Asian countries.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 11 -- President Johnson's Cabinet and top advisers got a preview today of the educational message he will send to Congress tomorrow and gave it rave notices.

Martin Canin's recital in Town Hall on Sunday night was his fourth here since he made his New York debut in 1958. The pianist, a teacher at Juilliard and other schools, played what might be termed a freshly conventional program.

NEW ROCHELLE, Jan. 11 -- Mayors from Westchester County towns served by the New Haven Railroad have been invited to a meeting here tomorrow to plan steps to prevent a proposed shut down of commuter service between here and New York.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 11 -- Malaysia last week renewed her request to the United States for favorable credit terms in purchasing anti-guerrilla jet aircraft, but the Administration's policy is to avoid providing military assistance to the Malaysians.
A Columbia University official called yesterday for community wide planning in Morningside Heights to resolve conflicts between the institutions there and residents.
Although there was a strike on the waterfront yesterday, there were few pickets, few ships and few longshoremen who knew precisely why the were on strike.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 11 (AP) -- Six Republican Senators are drawing up a health care plan for the aged that Senator Leverett Saltonstall says would cover some doctors' fees, going beyond the measure proposed by President Johnson.

The father of a 19-year-old youth filed a $1 million suit against the city yesterday, charging that his son had lost an eye as a result of being shot while helping a policeman chase a speeding motorist.

PARIS, Jan. 11 -- A crewman of the liner France was arrested today in Le Havre on a charge of smuggling shortly after it was announced that another crew member was found hanged in one of the ship's boiler rooms.

A week of the bitterest kind of partisan infighting has kept the Democratic majorities from organizing either house of the New York State Legislature. Today they equal the unenviable record of disunity set by the Republicans in the Assembly 28 years ago. Unless they agree soon on competent leaders, they will destroy the finest opportunity to make a record for useful public service the state's Democrats have had in this generation.

MANILA, Jan. 11 -- Efforts to resolve the dispute between the Philippines and Malaysia over territory in the Malaysian state of Sabah, formerly the British crown colony of North Borneo, appear to have reached an impasse.

WASHINGTON, Jan, 11 (AP) -- Spokesmen for several communications companies told the Federal Communications Commission today that timetables for constructing ground stations for a space communications system could be met if the F.C.C. decided promptly who was to operate the stations.
Details of a privately financed $700,000 addition to Gracie Mansion, the Mayor's official residence, were announced yesterday. Construction is expected to start in May and be completed late in 1966.

Jay Warhaftig, a super-star basketball player at Forest Hills High School two years ago, returned to Queens last night in the uniform of the Creighton Bluejays of Omaha. The opponent was St. John's. Instead of being the conquering hero, he was almost in tears at the end of the game and said through clenched teeth, "I'll never return to St. John's again."

MINEOLA, L.I., Jan. 11 -- In an attempt to take bureaucratic note of suburban man's plight on a digging-out day such as today, the Nassau County Department of Public Works has issued a pamphlet entitled "The Suburbanite's Guide to Snow."
MOSCOW, Jan. 11 -- The Supreme Court of the Russian Republic has called for an intensified drive against the cheating of customers in stores and restaurants.

DURGAPUR, India, Jan. 10 -- Financing a political party in a poor country presents problems, but the Indian National Congress, which has ruled this nation since independence, has found some unusual solutions.
It would seem that the last thing a subway advertiser would want is to have his posters scrawled on with everything from eyebrow pencils to lipstick.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 11 (AP) -- Legislation to reduce the gold-cover requirement for currency and certain Federal Reserve deposits will probably not be considered until after President Johnson's annual economic report is filed later this month.

MIAMI, Jan. 11 (AP) -- The president of the American Bar Association urged the legal profession and news media today to find a "sensible balance" between freedom of the press and guaranteeing an accused person a fair trial.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 11 (AP) -- The Navy disclosed today that it had acted on 20 safety recommendations designed to prevent another disaster like the loss of the atomic submarine Thresher.
Edward Auer, pianist, made his New York solo debut on the Young Concert Artists Series last night at Carnegie Recital Hall.

THE New York City resident who is overweight or underweight or who needs assistance in following a physician-prescribed diet or the answer to a legitimate question on nutrition can call on the extensive services of the New York City Bureau of Nutrition.
BOSTON, Jan. 11 (UPI) -- A master's hearing in connection with the status of the Florida route of Northeast Airlines was postponed today for the third time.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Jan. 11 -- The Soviet Union and four countries in the Soviet bloc have made payments to the United Nations in the past two weeks, but only Bulgaria has paid enough to insure her voting rights in the General Assembly.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 11 (UPI) -- The Defense Department announced new instructions today to guide its officials in stamping information with "top secret" and "confidential" labels.

The entrance of the New York City Center of Music and Drama into Lincoln Center is the best news that has come out of that conflict-swept cultural compound in recent months. For over twenty years the City Center has provided New Yorkers with lively, often provocative, cultural enterprises. In the process it has built up a world-famous ballet company and a progressive opera house staffed almost entirely by American artists.
Roy R. Neuberger, a 62-year-old-stockbroker, was elected president of the New York Society for Ethical Culture at a meeting of the fellowship's board of trustees yesterday.
CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Jan. 11 -- Dr. Richard E. Neustadt of Columbia University was named today associate dean of the Harvard Graduate School of Public Administration and a professor of government.
DETROIT, Jan. 11 -- Settlement of Detroit's six-day strike and lockout was reached today at all hotels except the Statler-Hilton.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 11 -- Vice President-elect Hubert H. Humphrey told a legislative conference of the American Federation of Labor and Congress of Industrial Organizations today that Congress would enact day that Congress would enact a program for hospital and nursing home care for the elderly under Social Security "before the first flower of spring."

PITTSBURGH, Jan. 11 (AP) -- Ray Scott's 10-foot jump shot with 18 seconds left, gave the Detroit Pistons a 128-127 victory over the Los Angeles Lakers in a National Basketball Association game at the Civic Arena tonight.

Authorities put added pressure on dealers in stolen gems yesterday in an effort to recover the DeLong Star Ruby and five other stones stolen from the American Museum of Natural History and believed to be intact.
The Chicago Mercantile Exchange announced yesterday that it planned to begin futures trading in dressed beef "sometime in February."

A convention of viola players turned up at Carnegie Recital Hall Sunday night to hear the opening concert in a three-part series aimed at improving the status of the viola as a solo instrument. Paul Doktor, organizer of the series, "The Solo Viola: Three Centuries," shared the stage as violist with Artur Balsam as pianist.
CORPUS CHRISTI, Tex., Jan. 11 (AP) -- Paul Amos Sandblom, once called a genius of finance, was convicted of fraud today after pleading no contest in Federal court.
SHERMAN STEARNS, who died here yesterday, was one of the leading American bridge players before World War II. Most of his successes were gained as a member of the legendary Four Aces team.
Memorabilia of 13 Presidents -- from Washington's telescope to Woodrow Wilson's typewriter -- will form a new exhibit in the United States pavilion when the World's Fair opens again in the spring.
The stock market marked time again yesterday as traders pondered the impact of an East Coast dock strike and a new report on health and smoking.

The beginning of definite decline in cigarette consumption, now officially reported, can only mean an improvement in the nation's health. Surgeon General Luther L. Terry says Federal surveys show that the percentage of men and women smoking now is smaller than in 1962, before publication of his definitive report on the close correlation between smoking and health hazards.

WHEN the late Bert Bell was the Commissioner of the National Football League, his office would be flooded at this time of the year by letters from insistent fans. The Grandstand Quarterbacks scoffed at the attempt for the extra point after touchdown as an archaic time waster. The professionals were so proficient, said the self-appointed experts, that the conversion had become automatic.

WHEN the late Bert Bell was the Commissioner of the National Football League, his office would be flooded at this time of the year by letters from insistent fans. The Grandstand Quarterbacks scoffed at the attempt for the extra point after touchdown as an archaic time waster. The professionals were so proficient, said the self-appointed experts, that the conversion had become automatic.

PARIS, Jan. 11 -- Cyrille Adoula, former Premier of the Congo, called today for the elimination of his successor, Moise Tshombe, from the country's political life and for negotiations with the Congolese rebels.

One morning last September, in a narrow, four-foot-deep hole in the middle of 57th Street and the Avenue of the Americas, men digging for the new subway extension came upon a 20-inch pipe that was not shown on any of the utility maps.
A Federal grand jury is investigating a charge that a prostitute was taken from New York to visit a Federal prisoner lodged in the Hudson County Jail in Jersey City.
PANAMA, Jan. 11 -- A crowd of preparatory students of the Panama National Institute demonstrated at the Presidential Palace this morning after they burned an American flag on their campus.
JERUSALEM (Israeli Sector) -- In an unfinished hall of the New Bezalel Art Museum a Persian mosaic has been installed.
PARIS, Jan. 11 -- Janos Peter, Hungary's Foreign Minister, declared his interest today in the French Government's ideas on an independent and enlarged Europe.

ROME, Jan. 1 -- Pope Paul VI, in an address to members of the Sacred Roman Rota, or high tribunal of the Roman Catholic Church, said today that every "culpable delay" in the performance of justice is "in itself an act of injustice."

PARIS, Jan. 11 -- The United States has won first place in the short features section at the Fifth International Film Festival for Youth at Cannes with the movie "The March," directed by James Blue. "The March" is a film of the civil rights March on Washington in 1963.

ATHENS, Jan. 11 -- Mr. Niarchos said that, while negotiations over the sale of his tankers and freighters to an American corporation were still in progress, the talks had "not reached the conclusive stage."
THE more people talk of peace the more they seem to enjoy violence in the arts. But are spy thrillers moral equivalents for war?
WASHINGTON, Jan. 11 -- Senator Richard B. Russell said today that there could be no victory over the Communist insurgents in South Vietnam unless "a more stable government" was established in Saigon.

The impact on Westchester and Putnam Counties of the state's limited-profit housing programs will be discussed at a dinner meeting tomorrow sponsored by the Builders Institute of Westchester and Putnam Counties.
Setting-up operations for the National Motor Boat Show began on schedule yesterday, but the timetable dragged anchor later as a result of the weekend snowstorm.
The battle lines are being drawn for what may be the first proxy fight of 1965.

Roy Wilkins, executive director of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People, said yesterday that he agreed with Police Commissioner Michael J. Murphy that talk of race rioting next summer should stop.
The Celanese Corporation of America, leading domestic producer of acetate fibers, announced yesterday the appointment of Alexander R. Cochran and Frank J. Pizzitola as group vice presidents.
New York longshoremen who defied their leaders to vote down a new contract and go on strike will be asked to vote on the contract a second time.

The New York Choral Society is moving up. At the beginning a few years ago, it performed in Carnegie Recital Hall. Then it graduated to Town Hall. Last night it appeared in Carnegie Hall, offering nothing less than Bach's B minor Mass, conducted by its founder, Martin Josman.
Miss Mildred Custin, president of the Bonwit Teller stores in Philadelphia, has been named president of the 721 Corporation, the subsidiary of Genesco, Inc., that controls all 12 Bonwit stores.
WARSAW, Jan. 10 -- To the newcomer, the sky over Warsaw seems to be gray all day.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 11 -- The Treasury bill rate showed mixed movements today, with the rate on three-month bills down and that for six-month bills up from last Monday's auction.

MIAMI, Jan. 11 (AP) -- The president of the Florida Council for Senior Citizens says thousands of old people are living together out of wedlock in the Miami area because marriage would mean loss of Social Security payments.

IF Dr. Richard Elliott Neustadt's new associates at Harvard want to communicate with him they had better wait until after he has had his breakfast, according to someone who has known him well for almost 20 years.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 11 -- An agreement establishing duty-free trade in automobiles and parts between the United States and Canada is expected to be signed shortly, possibly within a week, official sources disclosed today.

The Times of Jan. 5 reports that at long last the city has reluctantly applied to the striking welfare workers the law which forbids such strikes to those who choose public employment. This is a step in the right direction. But the chances seem good that rule by demonstration and picketing will continue to be encouraged.
WASHINGTON, Jan 12 -- President Johnson has been condemned often enough as an artful political dodger, but there are times when a little artful dodging serves the nation better than anything else.
An increase in the number of children killed in fires prompted Mayor Wagner to call upon parents yesterday to establish a "good neighbor" system of baby-sitting to avoid leaving them alone.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 12 -- Total business inventories rose by $700 million in November, far above the average for the earlier months of the year, the Commerce Department reported today.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, Jan. 12 -- Buddhist leaders, supported by a general strike in central Vietnam, demanded today that the Government resign.

Grete Sultan, pianist, gave a Schubert program at Town Hall last night. As in past appearances, her playing was notable for a sense of naturalness and for warm, patient musicality. She made everyone feel, "This is just the way it is meant to be."
Stock prices continued to rise on a broad front in moderately active trading yesterday on the American Stock Exchange.
GENEVA, Jan. 12 -- The International Commission of Jurists said today that it had new evidence that the "domination and persecution" of the Tibetan people by Communist China were continuing unabated.

ROME -- One of postwar Europe's most interesting features has been the rise and fall of Catholic Socialism. Within twenty years we have seen this political movement gain huge power in France, Italy and West Germany -- and then slowly start to wither.
President Johnson has promoted Capt. Frank V. Helmer, Chief of Staff of the Third Coast Guard District, to the rank of rear admiral, it was announced yesterday. The appointment is effective July 1.
LEOPOLDVILLE, the Congo, Jan. 12 -- Premier Moise Tshombe rejected today former Premier Cyrille Adoula's plan for a political solution of the Congo crisis.
Jerome F. Healy Jr. was unanimously re-elected to a one-year term as the president of the New York Athletic Club last night at the organization's 96th annual meeting here.

HARTFORD, Jan. 12 -- Republican and Democratic leaders ended months of wrangling by reaching agreement today on a bill to reapportion both houses of Connecticut's General Assembly in line with the United States Supreme Court's one-man-one-vote ruling.
LONDON -- In the hills outside Colchester, the new University of Essex has taken its first batch of students into a bold experiment in higher education.

MOSCOW, Jan. 12 -- The Soviet Communist party newspaper Pravda printed today a heavily edited version of a report on the work of the Chinese Communist Government submitted to the National People's Congress (Parliament) last month by Premier Chou En-lai.

A new 27-minute movie, "Full Circle," calls attention to the role of the Mental Health Film Board. In its fifteenth year of operation, the independent, nonprofit organization now has more than 10,000 film prints circulating internationally in psychiatric, educational and community centers.

It has often been suggested that Soviet-American student and scholar exchanges be expanded well beyond what a Times Editorial writer recently characterized as the pitifully small number of individuals whose exchanges are actually made possible each year by the official agreements.

SAN DIEGO, Jan. 12 -- This city's blighted downtown area was aglow with diamonds and civic pride this evening with the grand opening of San Diego's 3,000-seat Civic Theater.
A number of the season's debutantes will be presented on Feb. 12 at the fifth annual dinner dance of the Military Order of the Loyal Legion and the Dames of the Loyal Legion.
In Northport, L.I., people stared at the boat and scratched their heads.
PARIS -- "Education by work and for work. This must be the motto of our students and university."
The Federal Reserve Bank of New York, in more forceful language than it has used in a long time, expressed concern yesterday about the possibility of inflation.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 12 -- The Roman Catholic Church threw its qualified support today to President Johnson's sweeping educational program.
TENAFLY, N.J., Jan. 12 -- A search is on here for a youth who played havoc yesterday with the Tenafly school system because he did not want to go to class in the snow.
The recent sit-in and demonstrations at the University of California, with their insurrectionist overtones, have focused attention on student movements.

ATLANTA -- The desegregation of public schools in the South made almost as much progress in 1964 as in all the previous nine years since the Supreme Court declared the doctrine of separate but equal schools unconstitutional.
The Cigarette Advertising Code, which went into effect on Jan. 1, will produce some subtle though significant changes in the labeling of most cigarette packs.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Jan. 12 -- The United States has formally rejected African-Asian proposal to resume the General Assembly's work with normal voting while efforts continue to settle the dispute over assessments.
WASHINGTON -- The 88th Congress that adjourned last fall was proudly hailed as the "Education Congress" by President Johnson.
LONDON, Jan. 12 -- The American Telephone and Telegraph Corporation can no longer collect transistor royalties in Britain, a High Court judge has ruled.

When James B. Conant co-authored a high school chemistry textbook more than 40 years ago, it would not have occurred to him that he would some day be the most influ ential voice in American education.

Vincent John Rao, 70-year-old millionaire Mafia figure, was granted immunity from prosecution yesterday by Federal Judge Charles T. Tenney to testify before a special Federal grand jury. It is investigating the Mafia family headed by Thomas (Three-Finger Brown) Luchese.
THE women of the Vice President's family will have a New York hairdresser to coif them for the inaugural festivities.

LONDON, Jan. 12 (UPI) -- The British Empire heavyweight champion, Henry Cooper, scored a fifth-round technical knockout over Dick Wipperman of Buffalo tonight after flooring the American twice during the round.

The New York World's Fair, which has said it will go all out this year to attract people it failed to attract last year, announced yesterday that it was increasing the admission price for adults from $2 to $2.50.

The management of the American Metal Products Company sent a letter to stockholders yesterday advising them not to accept the offer made by the Management and Capital Company to purchase 300,000 shares of the common stock of American Metal Products at $24 a share.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 12 -- United States officials and informed diplomats think Cuba is seeking an invitation to the African-Asian conference in Algiers this spring while she is arranging to step up her guerrilla-training programs for Africans.
BRUSSELS, Jan. 12 -- Petroleum workers in nearby countries today voiced support for the 5,000 Belgian workers who struck yesterday.
